title: 110_hr1089
content: The Act may be cited as the "Project BioShield Material Threats Act of 2007" and addresses material threats. The "Project BioShield Material Threats Act of 2007" amends the Public Health Service Act to address material threats by redesignating clauses, moving subclauses, and utilizing existing risk assessments. The Homeland Security Secretary shall utilize existing risk assessments for threat assessments and determinations of chemical, biological, radiological, and nuclear agents to facilitate the assessment of countermeasures. The Homeland Security Secretary will group agents to aid in assessing countermeasures for chemical, biological, radiological, and nuclear threats, facilitating the evaluation by the Secretary of Health and Human Services. This includes categorizing countermeasures that can address multiple agents. Countermeasures may address multiple agents for adverse health consequences, not requiring a specific grouping to assess different categories of countermeasures. The Homeland Security Secretary must complete determinations for certain national-security concerns related to chemical, biological, radiological, and nuclear agents by December 31, 2007. A report to Congress is also required. The Homeland Security Secretary must report to Congress within 30 days of completing threat or risk assessments. Risk assessment is defined as a scientific analysis of agents incorporating threat, vulnerability, and consequence information. Authorization of appropriations under the Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to authorize additional appropriations for threat assessments in fiscal year 2008. This includes conducting risk assessments when no existing assessments are available.
